NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Almost 8 or 10

2. How many of these were bachelor's homes? 6

3. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Over a week

4. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sunday

5. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Without an invitation

What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? In the evening

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "make pot luck" used, or was some other expression common?) "Stay and have a clean belly."

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Tea or coffee

5. Did the whole family go? or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? I was a bachelor

6. Did you ever have "beast" when; groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "beast" were for, and how often they occurred.

Bees for putting up buildings and for seed up and harvesting in case of illness

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Were these parties more nearly of a public nature?

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, once a week, once every two weeks, once a month, etc.? No

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? About 8 or 10.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 6

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once a week.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sunday.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Without an invitation.

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take pot luck" used, or was some other expression common?) "Stay have a clean bath."

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Tea or coffee.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? I was a bachelor.

6. Did you ever have "beans" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes.

Did you remember about such gatherings, having dates if possible, tell me. One been went for, and how often they occurred.

Bees for putting up buildings and for seed up and harvesting in case of illness.

Was this entertaining used much at a public sale?
